entry.title: Media Manipulation
entry.content:
Following the shooting of Gabrielle Giffords, a large number of left leaning media outlets criticised the right wing media’s hype and extremism. Dan Lyons took them to task:

The problem began when news became tied to profits. The networks at one time used to run news as a loss leader, subsidized by entertainment. When that changed, and news started chasing ratings (and dollars), the problem began. When dollars started to dry up, things only got worse. Networks became desperate and resorted to making the news more like entertainment.

The Internet made things worse, in two ways. First, the Internet exacerbated the decline in revenues, and heightened the desperation in the news business. Trust me, I’m in a position to know, because I’m in the business of seeing just how far I can make news people bend in order to keep getting my advertising dollars. That influence is stronger now than it has ever been. The TV networks and magazines and newspapers are desperate and terrified. Stuff that 10 years ago they would have thrown back in our face they now do willingly — in fact, they don’t even wait for us to suggest it. They suggest it themselves.

But second, and more important, the Internet created an outlet for competing and often crazy voices. It gave birth to a new kind of “news.” Despite what the new-media pundits claim, the much-celebrated “citizen journalism” was all too often just noisy crap and propaganda.

Most of the news is written by interns that only get hired if they drive enough clicks to their linkbait articles:

It’s garbage precisely because online news sites are not primarily created to report news. They’re created to make money. Problem is, it’s nearly impossible to make money doing what they do. So they resort to ever more desperate tricks.

Why is so much online “news” reported in slideshow format? To gin up clicks. Not because it is a better way to consume news, because, please. Why is HuffPo so crowded with sensationalistic tabloid junk about celebrity boobs and fluffy “lists” of “the deadliest ice creams.” (And just about everyone else, too. )

Ryan Holiday gave a keynote at TNW about how bad glorified blog journalism is, and how easy it is to exploit media into running “controversial” linkbait stories, like Sasha Grey in an American Apparel ad campaign.

entry.title: Tecnoutopianism
entry.content:
I was going to write a post on Ivy League universities backing Massive Open Online Courses though edX and other providers, and started thinking back to the discussion of the OLPC project in 2007. Widespread media coverage showed Kofi Annan holding a prototype laptop with a hand crank and repeated the claim that the device would eventually be available for $100. The hand crank and the $100 price tag were unachievable, and major glitches in the first version of the laptops dampened the hype surrounding the project.

Vaclav Smil, professor emeritus of environment and geography at the University of Manitoba commented on the media’s tendency to see technology as a magic solution to intractable problems:

So the answers are not technological but political: better economic policies, better education, better trade policies.

Right. Today, as you know, everything is “innovation.” We have problems, and people are looking for fairy-tale solutions—innovation like manna from heaven falling on the Israelites and saving them from the desert. It’s like, “Let’s not reform the education system, the tax system. Let’s not improve our dysfunctional government. Just wait for this innovation manna from a little group of people in Silicon Valley, preferably of Indian origin.”

You people at WIRED—you’re the guilty ones! You support these people, you write about them, you elevate them onto the cover! You really messed it up. I tell you, you pushed this on the American public, right? And people believe it now.

Smil notes that the idea of efficiency gains in every sector is “Moore’s curse”

You call this Moore’s curse—the idea that if we’re innovative enough, everything can have yearly efficiency gains.

It’s a categorical mistake. You just cannot increase the efficiency of power plants like that. You have your combustion machines—the best one in the lab now is about 40 percent efficient. In the field they’re about 15 or 20 percent efficient. Well, you can’t quintuple it, because that would be 100 percent efficient. Impossible, right? There are limits. It’s not a microchip.

The same thing is true in agriculture. You cannot increase the efficiency of photosynthesis. We improve the performance of farms by irrigating them and fertilizing them to provide all these nutrients. But we cannot keep on doubling the yield every two years. Moore’s law doesn’t apply to plants.

Benjamin Bratton made similar talks in a TEDx talk about technological utopianism overlooking the difficult problems in philosophy and economics:

The key rhetorical device for TED talks is a combination of epiphany and personal testimony (an “epiphimony” if you like ) through which the speaker shares a personal journey of insight and realisation, its triumphs and tribulations.

What is it that the TED audience hopes to get from this? A vicarious insight, a fleeting moment of wonder, an inkling that maybe it’s all going to work out after all? A spiritual buzz?

I’m sorry but this fails to meet the challenges that we are supposedly here to confront. These are complicated and difficult and are not given to tidy just-so solutions. They don’t care about anyone’s experience of optimism. Given the stakes, making our best and brightest waste their time – and the audience’s time – dancing like infomercial hosts is too high a price. It is cynical.

Also, it just doesn’t work.

Recently there was a bit of a dust up when TEDGlobal sent out a note to TEDx organisers asking them not to not book speakers whose work spans the paranormal, the conspiratorial, new age “quantum neuroenergy”, etc: what is called woo. Instead of these placebos, TEDx should instead curate talks that are imaginative but grounded in reality. In fairness, they took some heat, so their gesture should be acknowledged. A lot of people take TED very seriously, and might lend credence to specious ideas if stamped with TED credentials. “No” to placebo science and medicine.

But … the corollaries of placebo science and placebo medicine are placebo politics and placebo innovation. On this point, TED has a long way to go.

Perhaps the pinnacle of placebo politics and innovation was featured at TEDx San Diego in 2011. You’re familiar I assume with Kony2012, the social media campaign to stop war crimes in central Africa? So what happened here? Evangelical surfer bro goes to help kids in Africa. He makes a campy video explaining genocide to the cast of Glee. The world finds his public epiphany to be shallow to the point of self-delusion. The complex geopolitics of central Africa are left undisturbed. Kony’s still there. The end.

You see, when inspiration becomes manipulation, inspiration becomes obfuscation. If you are not cynical you should be sceptical. You should be as sceptical of placebo politics as you are placebo medicine.

entry.title: New Map Shows the Harm of the Anti-Vaccine Movement
entry.content:
A new map by the Council on Foreign Relations shows the rising number of vaccine preventable diseases in first world contries. After Andrew Wakefield took out a patent on a single Measels vaccine he falsified a study that appeared to show that appeared to show that the Measels, Mumps and Rubella triple antigen was unsafe for children, proposing his own patented vaccine as a “safer” alternative. Even after Wakefield’s paper has been retracted for innacuracy, and he was struck off the medical register for “dishonest”, “unethical” and “callous” behaviour, anti-vaccine hysteria continues to spread thoughout the world. The drop in MMR vaccination rates in Wales to below 80% has caused a widespread measels outbreak, leaving parents of infected teenagers feeling betrayed by the lies of the anti-vaccine movement:

Wakefield MMR fraud comes home to roost in Wales
Australian ABC Lateline programme looks at the early-2013 outbreak of measles in Wales UK. A recent measles fatality is likely linked to the Andrew Wakefield MMR fraud which led to a baseless reduction in uptake of the MMR vaccine. It’s apparent that now fear of the demonstrable harm of measles outweighs the fallacious fear of MMR. Notifications equal 800 since November 2012 - approximately 7 times that for the entire year of 2012. The vast majority of parents now accept that the “callous” and deregistered Wakefield is a charlatan and a fraud.

Interestingly, Wakefield is only the latest in a long line of cranks opposed to the vaccination of children. I recently came across a talk by Professor Gareth Williams on the history of the anti-vaccine movement, going right back to Jenner himself. Some doctors opposed cowpox vaccination as smallpox cases were a large portion of their business, but most interestingly many people found religious arguments against vaccination. Theologians in France and England argued that ”diseases are sent by Providence for the punishment of sin” and suggested that Job’s boils and ulcers were a result of cowpox vaccination by Satan. One of the most wacko opponents of the Jennerian society wrote that smallpox helped to lower the size of poor families:

why is it not remembered that in the populous parts of the Metropolis, where the abundance of children exceed the means of providing food, and raiment for them, this pestilential disease is considered as a merciful provision on the part of Providence, to lessen the burthen of a poor man’s family ?

Interestingly, while most doctors (Wakefield excluded) would never seek to harm their patients to increase their own business, many pastors coninue to teach that children should not be vaccinated against infectious diseases. Measels outbreaks have been observed in areas with low vaccination rates, commonly correlated with high numbers of evangelical megachurches. Unfortunately, a number of churches order their congregation to eschew medical treatment in favour of prayer, which Republican lawmakers protect as “religious freedom”, even after a spate of preventable deaths.

entry.title: Phil Zuckerman on the Basis for a Civil Society
entry.content:
Phil Zuckerman recently took part in a debate with David Marshall on whether religion or secularism is a better basis for a civil society. After initially refusing to post the video online because they thought Zuckerman won, the church caved and the video is up.

The Great Debate: Marshall vs. Zuckerman (Christianity vs. Secular Humanism)
Does Christianity or secular humanism provide a better foundation for civil society? That is the question that is going to addressed between two scholars, Dr. David Marshall and Dr. Phillip Zuckerman, a Christian and an atheist. David Marshall is the founder and director of the Kuai Mu Institute for Christianity and World Cultures, and the author of four books, including The Truth Behind the New Atheism: Responding to the Emerging Challenges to God and Christianity (Harvest House Publishers). Phil Zuckerman is a professor of sociology and secular studies at Pitzer College in Claremont, CA. He is the author most recently of Faith No More: Why People Reject Religion (Oxford University Press, 2011) and Society Without God (NYU Press, 2008).

Zuckerman stuck to the facts about why largely secular post-Chrsitian societies around the world are doing better on most indicators than the most religious societies, while Marshall presented weak anecdotes of individual conversion experiences and straw men about how communists and vikings are bad people. The pastor of the church said “It just didn’t go the way we wanted it to go. We were not represented well.”

Zuckerman has noted that many European societies that score well on social indicators also have low rates of Chrsitian belief. Only 18% of Swedes believe in heaven, 10% believe in hell and 3% believe that the Bible is the literal word of God, among the lowest rates in the world. In Denmark, women’s labour force participation doubled in the ’70s and ’80s, rapidly changing the model of femininity valued by young women. Social changes like these supported by neoliberal governments, including the banning of prosletyzing in schools, and the provision of free healthcare to all have quickly caused generational decline in religion as the state Lutheran church struggles to market itself.

Zuckerman eloquently criticised the bible belt states for high rates of divorce, teen pregnancy, sexual assault, diabetes, child abuse, unemployment and murder. He has a long history of criticising the political hypocrisy of the white evangelical power base, that claims evolution is wrong, but tend to support policies that could be described as “Social Darwinism.”

The results from a recent poll published by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life reveal what social scientists have known for a long time: White Evangelical Christians are the group least likely to support politicians or policies that reflect the actual teachings of Jesus.

Zuckerman has an excellent analysis of the global decline of faith on Edge.org. One interesting fact about the general decline of Chrstianity in America is how gender plays a factor in mixed faith households:

Rather than Amerofaith becoming deeply patriarchal as Longman thinks, it is increasingly feminine. Women church goers greatly outnumber men, who find church too dull. Here’s the kicker. Children tend to pick up their beliefs from their fathers. So, despite a vibrant evangelical youth cohort, young Americans taken as a whole are the least religious and most culturally tolerant age group in the nation.

He notes that the well resourced churches are consolidating believers rather than expanding the faithful

Even the megachurch phenomenon is illusory. A spiritual cross of sports stadiums with theme parks, hi-tech churches are a desperate effort to pull in and satisfy a mass-media jaded audience for whom the old sit in the pews and listen to the standard sermon and sing some old time hymns does not cut it anymore. Rather than boosting church membership, megachurches are merely consolidating it.

While Zuckerman notes that he was well remunerated for travelling to take part in the professionally recorded debate, the decision of the church to initially refuse to publish the video demonstrates that content matters more than its presentation. The trend of religion being on the nose for the last hundred years will continue as churches struggle to cover up their mistakes in an age of social media, no matter how well they learn to speak with ‘Gen Y’.

Politifact rates Brandis’s statement as half true.

While Abbott noted in the debate that same sex marriage was an “important” issue for his lesbian sister, his view on the issue has not “evolved” but goes against the majority of the Australian population. Figures from the ABC’s Vote Compass survey of 422,000 respondents show that the majority of Australians support same sex marriage, and 70% of those under 34 do. This is in line with previous opinion polls finding that about 60% of the country now supports same sex marriage.

There’s an old quote “every time you hear an ambulance siren, an opponent of gay rights is leaving the world or a supporter is entering it”. In reality, with NZ and the UK passing gay marriage laws it’s already a lost argument. The UK law will come into effect in 2014, I don’t think the Christian lobby can hold the issue back that much longer.

entry.title: Common Cognitive Mistakes and How to Prevent Them
entry.content:
Good post on the Buffer blog on cognitive errors. There’s good discussion of Dan Ariely’s work on anchoring and pricing, as well as this classic about the conjuction fallacy:

In 1983 Kahneman and Tversky tested how illogical human thinking is by describing the following imaginary person:

Linda is thirty-one years old, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy. As a student, she was deeply concerned with issues of discrimination and social justice, and also participated in antinuclear demonstrations.

The researchers asked people to read this description, and then asked them to answer this question:

Which alternative is more probable?

  1. Linda is a bank teller.
  2. Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement. Here’s where it can get a bit tricky to understand (at least, it did for me!)—If answer #2 is true, #1 is also true. This means that #2 cannot be the answer to the question of probability.

Unfortunately, few of us realize this, because we’re so overcome by the more detailed description of #2. Plus, as the earlier quote pointed out, stereotypes are so deeply ingrained in our minds that subconsciously apply them to others.

Roughly 85% of people chose option #2 as the answer. A simple choice of words can change everything.

Adding more detail or extra assumptions can make an event seem more plausible, even though the event necessarily becomes less probable. Kahneman and Tversky tried another experiment on probabilities:

Consider a regular six-sided die with four green faces and two red faces. The die will be rolled 20 times and the sequences of greens (G) and reds (R) will be recorded. You are asked to select one sequence, from a set of three, and you will win $25 if the sequence you chose appears on successive rolls of the die. Please check the sequence of greens and reds on which you prefer to bet.

  1. RGRRR
  2. GRGRRR
  3. GRRRRR

65% of respondents chose option 2 as the most likely bet, as it matches the colours of the 6 sides, even though the shorter sequence 1 requires less correct rolls to complete.

Another example of the conjunction fallacy

  1. “A complete suspension of diplomatic relations between the USA and the Soviet Union, sometime in 1983.”
  2. “A Russian invasion of Poland, and a complete suspension of diplomatic relations between the USA and the Soviet Union, sometime in 1983.”

Most respondents rate 2 as more likely than 1, even though 2 would necessarily entail 1, and it would be possible to have a complete suspension of diplomatic relations between the USA and USSR without invasion of any country, let alone Poland specifically.

In another example, people’s perception

Yamagishi (1997) showed that subjects judged a disease as more dangerous when it was described as killing 1,286 people out of every 10,000, versus a disease that was 24.14% likely to be fatal. Apparently the mental image of a thousand dead bodies is much more alarming, compared to a single person who’s more likely to survive than not.

But wait, it gets worse.

Suppose an airport must decide whether to spend money to purchase some new equipment, while critics argue that the money should be spent on other aspects of airport safety. Slovic et. al. (2002) presented two groups of subjects with the arguments for and against purchasing the equipment, with a response scale ranging from 0 (would not support at all) to 20 (very strong support). One group saw the measure described as saving 150 lives. The other group saw the measure described as saving 98% of 150 lives. The hypothesis motivating the experiment was that saving 150 lives sounds vaguely good—is that a lot? a little?—while saving 98% of something is clearly very good because 98% is so close to the upper bound of the percentage scale. Lo and behold, saving 150 lives had mean support of 10.4, while saving 98% of 150 lives had mean support of 13.6.

If you have the time, consider how you’d approach a problem like the Monty Hall problem or this classic problem on breast cancer screening:

1% of women at age forty who participate in routine screening have breast cancer. 80% of women with breast cancer will get positive mammographies. 9.6% of women without breast cancer will also get positive mammographies. A woman in this age group had a positive mammography in a routine screening. What is the probability that she actually has breast cancer?

While most doctors give the intuitive answer of 80%, working though with Baysean logic gives the answer of 7.8%. Yudowsky has a long explanation of the answer.

entry.title: Are Female Singers Too Sexualised?
entry.content:
Conservatives love to bemoan how “Hollywood values” are not in line with their own views, and how the views of young people differing from their own must be a result of the media and colleges having a “liberal bias”. While the media that people consume may be an embodiment of cultural values at the time, unless anything particularly eggregious is being marketed to children that have no understanding of society’s views then this is mostly an overreaction. This particularly plays into the way that people view female musicians, that tend to be criticised simultaneously for beeing too sexual and not sexy enough.

I’m going to briefly look at a few female performers, and the kinds of expectations placed on them by different sectors of the community.

Katy Perry - By the Grace of God

Katy Perry started her musical career as a Christian singer writing songs on theology and her love of Jesus. While her breakthough hit I Kissed a Girl attracted international attention for it’s playful insinuation of lesbian experimentation, Perry has never really sexualised her image relative to other stars.

In a June 2012 interview Perry noted that her next album “would be a much darker album than the previous one. It was inevitable, after what I went through.” She noted “When you lose something, all your foundations crumble-but that also leaves a big hole that’s open for something great to come through.” The album has gone in dark directions for some tracks, as billboard notes:

Self-help and astrological references abound on tracks like Spiritual and Legendary Lovers, reflecting Perry’s recent immersion in Transcendental Meditation and mindfulness therapy. Elsewhere, Perry pointedly confronts her turbulent recent history. The line “You sent a text/It’s like the wind changed your mind” from Ghost references how Brand delivered the news he wanted a divorce. By the Grace of God, meanwhile, begins with Perry lying on the floor of a bathroom, fighting suicidal thoughts. “That song is evident of how tough it really was at a certain point. I asked myself, ‘Do I want to endure? Should I continue living?’” Perry says. “All the songs are real-life moments. I can only write autobiographically. I put all the evidence in the music. I tell my fans if they want to know the real truth about stuff, just listen to the songs.”

Katy Perry - By the Grace of God (Live at iTunes Festival with broadcast audio and lyrics)
Perry’s dark ballard from the upcoming PRISM record written with Greg Wells emphasising spiritual themes. From videos here: http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLEz4f0nOvFIkXrYE-qhNBy2SbYVVXXnGU More info: http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/5740580/katy-perrys-prism-the-billboard-cover-story

A few of the lyrics are particularly interesting:

Thought I wasn’t enough
found I wasn’t so tough
Laying on the bathroom floor
We were living on a front line
and I felt the fault was all mine
Couldn’t take it anymore

By the grace of God
There was no other way
I picked myself back up
I knew I had to say
I put one foot in front of the other and I
Looked in the mirror and decided to stay
Wasn’t gonna let love take me out that way

Love is a reference to her ex-husband Brand.

I thank my sister for keeping my head above the water
When the truth was like swallowing sand
Now, every morning, oh there is no more morning
Oh, I can finally see myself again

I know I am enough, possible to be loved
It was not about me
Now I have to raise above
Let the Universe call the bluff
Yeah, the truth will set you free

The phrase the truth will set you free is a quote from Jesus speaking in John 8, leading many to speculate that this is a homage to her past as a singer in Christian contemporary music.

Miley Cyrus

When Destiny Hope Cyrus rose to fame after being cast in Disney’s Hannah Montanna, many were enamoured with the country singer’s daughter from the buckle of the bible belt. To add to her family friendly charm, she described her Christian faith as ”very important” and wrote about keeping the faith in The Climb. Some even saw her as part of a new movement of conservative Christian public figures that would bring the US back to social conservatism in a new great awakening:

Cyrus in 2007 described her stardom as being ”God’s will”, promising that she wouldn’t start going crazy under the spotlight.

In a pop culture filled with young hot starlets gone wild, isn’t Billy Ray worried that pretty Miley will soon start doing nutty Britney Spears-eque things, like not wearing underpants?

“She’s never wore underwear,” Billy Ray says without missing a beat.

“Dad!” Miley says.

Miley went on to present an increasingly edgy image, with most media outlets disproportionately covering her antics instead of actual news. This is the latest controvertial act:

Why would she do such a thing? Probably because Professor Lawrence Krauss has addled her brain:

Sinead O’Connor wrote an open letter to Cyrus, complaining that she regrets her record label pushing her to be too sexual. Cyrus responded that she was too busy to write back, though the whole thing has turned ugly with mental health issues being discussed publicly.

Amanda Palmer weighed in, commenting that she finds some performers want to be sexually powerful on stage, and that they themselves push to expose themselves more on stage, noting:

“It’s a Chinese finger trap that reflects the basic problems of our women-times: we’re either scolded for looking sexy or we’re scolded for not playing the game. Those who manage to find a perfect balance are rare, and the culture at large seems hellbent on undermining our ability to create that balance peacefully within ourselves. And weirdly, it’s generally women scolding other women…we’re our own worst enemies.”

Rhianna

“Pour it up” is very much on the pro-sex side of the equation by making a song about stripping, and about half of the youtube votes are negative.

entry.title: Why Popular Science and I Turn Off Comments
entry.content:
Popular Science recently announced that they are shutting down the comments for new articles, as they can skew the readers into distrusting the expertise of scientists. Recent studies have found that incivility in the comment section can alter the perception of the credibility of the articles they accompany. In one study, readers of a fake blog post on nanotechnology were asked to evaluate it’s impact, with one group exposed to vituperative comments:

Uncivil comments not only polarized readers, but they often changed a participant’s interpretation of the news story itself.
In the civil group, those who initially did or did not support the technology — whom we identified with preliminary survey questions — continued to feel the same way after reading the comments. Those exposed to rude comments, however, ended up with a much more polarized understanding of the risks connected with the technology.
Simply including an ad hominem attack in a reader comment was enough to make study participants think the downside of the reported technology was greater than they’d previously thought.

In a world where more and more discussion of contemporary issues happens online, this does not bode well for the public understanding of the importance of science, alread at all time lows. As people search out information about health online, “Dr Google” can mislead patients and present debunked information wrongly suggesting that vaccines don’t work. A decentralised media landscape should have the ability to route around authoritarian regimes that try to censor it, but what happens when it undermines the structures that support the public respect of useful institutions?

Carl Sagan fundamentaly believed that the populace deserved to be educated about science, so that political or religious charlatans wouldn’t lure them into the next deception. Noting that either the people control the government or the government controls the people, he fiercely advocated that the science of evolution be taught in public schools so that the people could choose to understand science for themselves:

Carl Sagan’s last interview with Charlie Rose (Full Interview)
Last interview with Charlie Rose

Benkler, in his 2006 book The Wealth of Networks portended a networked society enriched by freely available peer-produced cultural works in a shared online commons like wikipedia. The utipian visions of such an information ecosystem, however, have to be reconciled with the reality that most people are unaware of their own cognitive biases, and are increasingly polarised on science and other issues in the management of polities. Without educating people on cognative biases and getting them to understand the world as it is, not as they want it to be, then potentially a decentrilised internet will simply fracture people into tribal teams who all see things the same way. Unfortunately, some content algorithms are set up to give users content similar to what they’ve already seen potentially limiting their exposure to information that contradicts their beliefs. Similarly, asking a search engine to find information on “global warming science” or “global warming conspiracy” may find different sets of sites, without the questioner perceiving any bias in their own question, and assuming that the results they see are representitive of the information as a whole.

In conclusion to all of this, the reason I don’t have comments is that like Popular Science, I don’t think they’re particularly helpful.

entry.title: Sexual Politics in Rome
entry.content:
Pope Francis has recently made international headlines by suggesting that the Catholic Church is too focused on gays and abortion. This follows from his earlier comments that atheists who follow their conscience might be able to go to heaven and that he isn’t in a position to judge celibate gay Catholics. This is a major turnaround from the culture war style dealings with the public the church pushed under Benedict, culminating in the Manhattan Declaration’s popularity.

Most of the current culture war issues revolve around gender politics, and these disputes likely go back to the start of the church. This history channel documentary presents expert opinions on New Testament apocrypha, including the Acts of Paul and Thecla

Banned From The Bible - Secrets Of The Apostles
Travel back to the blistering sands of the Holy Land, into the onion-domed chapels of Eastern Orthodox churches and onto the pages of the Koran. Unearth the trail of chapters that were left out of the ultimate version of the Scriptures. Included in the Koran is “The Life of Adam and Eve,” a detailed account of the creation story written before Jesus was born. The incestuous account of “The Book of Jubilees” was included in the Orthodox Old Testament and the Dead Sea Scrolls. “The Book of Enoch,” an ancient bestseller, relates the story of the man said in Genesis to have walked with God and been assumed directly into heaven. This fascinating collection offers a fresh perspective on the figures at the foundation of faith.

Thecla, as the story goes, was a student of Paul’s that loved his preaching on asceticism and celibacy. After telling her fiance that she was no longer interested in marrying him, he became furious and sought out Paul to demand he stop teaching that virgins should remain chaste. He raised a multitude of angry husbands who were furious their wives stopped wanting sex, and brought Paul and Thecla to the governor, who condemned Paul to flogging and and Thecla to burning at the stake as a warning against their teachings. While Thecla was being brought to her pyre, she looked around for Paul, and saw in the crowd a vision of Jesus who ascended to heaven. Fixing her gaze on heaven as the pyre was lit, a miraculous hailstorm extinguished the flames, saving her. I find it interesting that while this story is entirely fictional, it has a number of similarities to the death of Joan of Arc.

Paul, it is said, then allowed Thecla to travel with him throughout the land, so long as she didn’t let her looks tempt the people. In Antioch, an magistrate called Alexander was taken with her, and grabbed her and kissed her as his way of proposition. Vowed to chastity, Thecla responded by knocking the crown off his head and ripping his cloak open so as to humiliate him in front of the people he ruled. Ashamed, Alexander took her to the governor who ordered her be thrown to the lions. Alexander had support from the men of the town, but the women of the town felt sympathy for the virgin and felt the punishment unjust. Before being cast into the amphitheatre to confront her fate, Thecla cried out in faith to her god to protect her innocence, and a she-lion fiercer than all the beasts fell down before her. The she-lion then killed the beasts that attacked Thecla, including male lions and a she-bear. This is probably a reference to Elisha’s she-bears, and Daniel’s lions.

Thecla and the lions by Gordon Napier

Next Thecla decided to baptise herself in a pool of sharks. Upon baptising herself in the name of Jesus, the sharks were struck with fire and lightning, and she was protected with a ring of fire. The women threw ointments into the field to knock out the other animals, so Alexander brought in his strongest bulls to have Thecla tied to. So the governor’s men tied a rope around Thecla’s waist to bulls that became enraged when hit by a hot poker in the nads. But the divine fire around Thecla burned off the rope fastened to the members of the bulls. When a powerful widow and relative of Caesar collapsed with worry for Thecla, the governor put an end to her trials fearing for his reputation, and officially pardoned Thecla. Thecla proclaimed the message of Christianity, converting many young men and women, and dressed as a man, led her new followers to find Paul who had run off amongst the commotion.

Thecla then went about the land preaching and performing miraculous healings, and set up a monastery where a large number of young women pledged their chastity. Tales of her miracles caused the sick in adjacent countries to travel to her for healing, making the local physicians furious at the competition, so they plotted to kill her. They decided that the virgin priestess must be raped to lose her powers, so conspired to pay local youths to assault her. They announced to her their intent to lie with her, before she cried out to heaven to save her chastity, and she ran into a miraculous fissure in a rock that closed up behind her, saving her one last time.

There’s a lot of things in this story that the early church fathers would have found objectionable, including the claim that Paul preached asceticism. But one of the most interesting things is how virginity went against the culture of the time. The story has Paul preaching that married couples should stay chaste, and while some loopy couples today manage this for two whole years most of the church’s preaching has changed to pro-natalist ideas. Interestingly, this may only have come after Paul and Jesus, as both believed that an apocalypse was coming in their lifetime, and children were unnecessary. Bart Ehrman has argued in Forged that 1 Thessalonians and parts of 1 Corinthians are a forgery of Pauline writings. This would actually fit with an asceticist Paul being watered down by later authors wanting to focus on childbearing, and making Christianity compatible with the Roman society of the time.

Justin Martyr, facing Roman persecution, presented his argument that Christianity was less of a threat to Roman order than atheistic philosophers like Socrates. The earlier church would have faced similar persecution, and had the similar desire to make Christianity seem compatible with the Roman culture of the time. In Book 1 of Politics Aristotle writes that the hierarchy of the state should be matched by the “building block” of the family:

Seeing then that the state is made up of households, before speaking of the state we must speak of the management of the household. The parts of the household are the persons who compose it, and a complete household consists of slaves and freemen. Now we should begin by examining everything in its least elements; and the first and least parts of a family are master and slave, husband and wife, father and children. We have therefore to consider what each of these three relations is and ought to be:—I mean the relation of master and servant, of husband and wife, and thirdly of parent and child.

Plato advocates husbands ruling over their wives, criticising Socrates for advocating for equality between the sexes:

A husband and father rules over wife and children, both free, but the rule differs, the rule over his children being a royal, over his wife a constitutional rule. For although there may be exceptions to the order of nature, the male is by nature fitter for command than the female, just as the elder and full-grown is superior to the younger and more immature… moral virtue belongs to all of them; but the temperance of a man and of a woman, or the courage and justice of a man and of a woman, are not, as Socrates maintained, the same; the courage of a man is shown in commanding, of a woman in obeying

Philo of Alexandria similarly reflected on the society of his time by documenting the importance of men controlling their families:

if you ask any one of them about their national laws or customs, they can all tell you at once, without any difficulty; and the husband appears to be a master, endowed with sufficient authority to explain these laws to his wife, a father to teach them to his children, and a master to his servants.”

Many Christian writers would have wanted to make Christianity compatible with these household codes, and the similar decrees that women submit to their husbands, save themselves in childbirth, and never preach (in Colossians, Ephesians, 1 Timothy, Titus and 1 Peter) may be a response to the Roman culture of the time. It may also be a way on clamping down on radical women’s movement of virgins that would have sprung up in the wake of texts like the Acts of Paul and Thecla, pushing for women to gain power over the men by denying their husbands sex - the one area in which they wielded considerable power. Even in times when women have jobs and education, there is widespread anxiety over the “sexualisation” of girls, as though female sexuality is some dangerous, destabilising force.

All non-apocalyptic religions emphasise marriage, childbearing and family. Studies have found that when people are in a room with highly attractive people, they are more drawn to religious ideas that emphasise monogamy. In nearly every religion, teachings can be conveniently cherry picked to conform to the type of reproductive strategy that the adherent wants to achieve.

entry.title: Politics Wrecks Your Brain
entry.content:
Confused Monkey

Everyone knows the old rule of avoiding bringing up religion and politics in polite company to keep discussions civil. Political disagreements often become pointed and vituperative because people who are otherwise open to new ideas can become defensive when their political views are questioned. While most people believe that others will see things their way if they simply had the right information, the reality is that people presented with new information will typically interpret in light of what they already know. A new study from Yale shows just how bad the problem can be, with people letting their political views get in the way of thinking clearly.

Dan Kahan presented students with a simple number problem, asking them to determine whether a certain intervention improves or worsens a problem. Respondents were presented with one version asking about skin rashes (a neutral problem) and another version asking them about gun control and crime (a deeply polarising ongoing political argument). The respondents were presented with the following table and asked whether the intervention worked:

Figuring out whether the cream works requires computing two ratios, and comparing whether the intervention worked better in the experimental group than the control group. In the experimental group, there is a 3:1 ratio of improvement to worsening, leading to the intuitive answer that the intervention works. But the correct answer is only found when that ratio is compared to the 5:1 improvement in the control group. As I’ve already written about, people can make errors in basic maths problems by settling for the intuitive answer, rather than double checking their work to find the correct one.

On average only 41% of respondents got the answer about skin care right, with more numerate respondents getting the answer right more of the time. Unfortunately, with the question on gun control, highly numerate Democrats and Republicans tended to get the answer right when the intuitive answer didn’t align with their political philosophy, but were unlikely to get the answer right when the intuitive answer agreed with their political philosophy. Kahan’s data suggests that people with high scientific literacy and numeracy are still likely to misinterpret scientific findings if they agree or disagree with their political biases. Earlier work found that people with a high level of scientific literacy, on average, are more sceptical of climate change, with views more politically polarised the more knowledgeable the individuals are.

When people are presented with information on the risks and opportunities of nanotechnology, those who oppose nuclear power usually oppose nanotechnology, and vice versa, as people interpret new information in line with their pre-existing beliefs. Philosophers and moral leaders have for millennia used parables and metaphors to present new ideas to students, getting them to reason about thought experiments outside of their intuitions about their current situation.

David Hume described reason as the “slave of the passions”, and Jonathan Haidt describes human cognition as an emotional elephant with a rational rider. We think with emotions faster than we consciously reason with logic. More often than not, the reasons we give for thinking one way or another are post-hoc rationalisations for intuitive emotional judgements. Haidt has suggested that many people see themselves in a tribe, with their own interests in opposition to the other team’s. People who support certain causes can see their identity as part of a group that believes in similar causes.

So while many people view the divisiveness of political discourse as the fault of the current media landscape, the reality is that these kinds of debates have been going on for all of history. In Emperor Justinius’s Byzantium in 532, political factions took sides on chariot racing in the Hippodrome. Two major factions existed, the Blues and Greens racing teams, with the Blues receiving support from the Emperor and his faction, and the Greens a more popular team. Consider the historian Procopius’s view on the politics of Byzantium in 532:

In every city the population has been divided for a long time past into the Blue and the Green factions; but within comparatively recent times it has come about that, for the sake of these names and the seats which the rival factions occupy in watching the games, they spend their money and abandon their bodies to the most cruel tortures, and even do not think it unworthy to die a most shameful death. And they fight against their opponents knowing not for what end they imperil themselves, but knowing well that, even if they overcome their enemy the fight, the conclusion of the matter for them will be to be carried off straight away to the prison, and finally, after suffering extreme torture, to be destroyed. So there grows up in them against their fellow men a hostility which has no cause, and at no time does it cease or disappear, for it gives place neither to the ties of marriage nor of relationship nor of friendship, and the case is the same even though those who differ with respect to these colours be brothers or any other kin

The horse races could kill and maim participants, and some of the supporters, in their colours would smuggle weapons into the stadium (that seated 150,000) to start fights with the supporters of the other team. These fights broke out not just because of the sport, but because the tribal identity of the sports teams lead their supporters to fight over political issues, and theological debates coming from the Fourth Ecumenical council. This culminated in a riot that Procopius estimated killed up to 30,000

Eliazar Yudkowsky has reflected on just how meaningless and pointless these tribal conflicts can be. In a thought experiment I love, he presents a politicised version of Plato’s cave, inviting reflection on a future society living underground with no vision of the sky. They have only scraps of human history describing a “cerulean” sky, and factions of Blues and Greens have fought violently for years over the interpretation of the colour of the sky. After growing exhausted with the constant conflicts over the issue, an uneasy truce develops. People continue to be entrenched into the “Blue” or “Green” way of thinking about political and cultural issues like taxation, based on battle lines drawn from the original debate.

I highly recommend reading Yudkowsky’s post in full to understand the power of the metaphor. Briefly, he presents different people reaching the surface and seeing the sky for the first time. For some Blues, the confirmation of a blue sky encourages them to want to break the truce and fight out the issue. For some Greens, the disconfirmation of everything they’ve lived for crushes them, and they must confront the cruel truth that while the reviled Blues are right. For the professor who’s always emphasised that both positions could be right, the single colour of the sky is too much of a risk to the harmony of society to embrace. For one Green, the admission that she was wrong for most of her life will hurt her family and leave her with few friends, but her committment to intellectual integrity requires her to announce her changed belief. The final traveller, seeing only the beauty and wonder of the sky, marvels at the new environment and decides to go exploring.

Knowing that political differences arise from the way that people deal with information, rather than a lack of information, leads me to belive that the last traveller probably has the best response. Sometimes you’ll find new information that other people wouldn’t accept, and it’s better just to explore the world without them.

entry.title: Kevin Rudd on Biblical Slavery
entry.content:
KRudd has received strong support on social media for his views on same sex marriage:

Rudd launches passionate gay marriage defence
Kevin Rudd rebukes a questioner on ABC Television’s Q&A program on the issue of whether he should have changed stance on gay marriage. Story: http://bit.ly/15upc7Z

Rudd further defended the views

Prime Minister Kevin Rudd on the Bible, same sex marriage, slavery, discrimination
The day after PM Kevin Rudd’s comments on Q&A to a Christian pastor, about same sex marriage and saying that the Bible sees slavery as ‘a natural condition’. 12:30pm, 3 September 2013, Tasmania- Reporter: Just on your exchange last night with a Christian pastor about same-sex marriage, are you concerned your position on marriage equality risks alienating the Christian vote? Kevin Rudd: You know something? This is a really interesting example of a question, because it’s about political perceptions of a given action. I’m concerned about what we do. I’m actually concerned about answering directly a question about what we do about all those Australians who are in same-sex relationships, who are asking for a basic exercise of human decency which is called ‘marriage equality’. And so, if it offends some people, so be it. But my job is to say what I am standing up for, what we would do if we are re-elected, and how we would go about doing it. And I’ve done that. And in my response to that fellow last night, when people start hurling Biblical quotes at me – I know a bit about my New Testament as well.
